articles.headline: Add Uncertainty to Your Financial Plans
articles.snippet: In an excerpt from “The One-Page Financial Plan,” the author suggests taking a best guess on the future, based on personal values.
articles.abstract: In an excerpt from “The One-Page Financial Plan,” the author suggests taking a best guess on the future, based on personal values.
articles.lead_paragraph: Human beings don’t like uncertainty, especially when we’re contemplating our financial futures. It’s not enough for us to think that we’ll have enough money to send our kids to college, or to retire. We want to know exactly how much money we’ll need to achieve those goals — and precisely how we’re going to get it.

articles.headline: Campaign Money Tests Wisconsin Justices’ Impartiality
articles.snippet: The State Supreme Court has scheduled arguments about a financing case that involves groups that spent millions backing some of the justices.
articles.abstract: The State Supreme Court has scheduled arguments about a financing case that involves groups that spent millions backing some of the justices.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — In an off year for major elections in Wisconsin, one race in 2011 unexpectedly turned into a full-blown battle: David Prosser, a Supreme Court justice seen as part of the court’s conservative majority, was fighting for his seat against a more liberal opponent, JoAnne Kloppenburg, a little-known assistant attorney general.

articles.headline: Be Your Guest? How About I Just Pay and Leave?
articles.snippet: For decades, Disney used the word, and today “guest” has sprung from the hospitality business and invaded retail, to some customers’ chagrin.
articles.abstract: For decades, Disney used the word, and today “guest” has sprung from the hospitality business and invaded retail, to some customers’ chagrin.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long line moves slowly. Clutching baskets of detergent, dental floss and such, the errand-running patrons of Walgreens assume their places with resignation, seeking only to pay and get out the door.

articles.headline: Yellen Says Fed Will Increase Rates Slowly
articles.snippet: The return to normalcy in monetary policy will be prolonged, the Fed chairwoman said, because the American economy remains fragile.
articles.abstract: The return to normalcy in monetary policy will be prolonged, the Fed chairwoman said, because the American economy remains fragile.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that the Fed planned to raise interest rates more slowly than in past recoveries because of the unusually fragile condition of the American economy.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted
articles.snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer.
articles.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, an Environmental Protection Agency committee determined that the popular weed killer Roundup might cause cancer. Six years later, in 1991, the agency reversed itself after re-evaluating the mouse study that had been the basis for the original conclusion.

articles.headline: Ellen Pao Loses Silicon Valley Bias Case Against Kleiner Perkins
articles.snippet: A jury rejected allegations of gender discrimination against the venture capital firm, after a hitch caused the judge to order further deliberations.
articles.abstract: A jury rejected allegations of gender discrimination against the venture capital firm, after a hitch caused the judge to order further deliberations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Silicon Valley’s most famous venture capital firms prevailed on Friday over a former partner in a closely watched suit claiming gender discrimination, but hardly got away unscathed.

articles.headline: Indiana Law Denounced as Invitation to Discriminate Against Gays
articles.snippet: A measure described as protecting religious freedom was assailed by political and business leaders because it could allow businesses to refuse service to gay couples.
articles.abstract: A measure described as protecting religious freedom was assailed by political and business leaders because it could allow businesses to refuse service to gay couples.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Indiana law that could make it easier for religious conservatives to refuse service to gay couples touched off storms of protest on Friday from the worlds of arts, business and college athletics and opened an emotional new debate in the emerging campaign for president.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: Ellen Pao Disrupts How Silicon Valley Does Business
articles.snippet: While the verdict on Friday was a defeat for Ms. Pao, the trial has blown open a conversation about the status of women in an industry that has always been buttoned up about its shortcomings.
articles.abstract: While the verdict on Friday was a defeat for Ms. Pao, the trial has blown open a conversation about the status of women in an industry that has always been buttoned up about its shortcomings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is enamored of “disrupters,” those shrewd, brave men — it is almost always men — who are hailed for enduring years of ridicule and risking everything to shake up the conventional order.

articles.headline: Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn
articles.snippet: Burning a 75-foot-tall pagan temple in a Republican Catholic enclave on the loyalist Protestant side of Londonderry seemed to many like a bad idea.
articles.abstract: Burning a 75-foot-tall pagan temple in a Republican Catholic enclave on the loyalist Protestant side of Londonderry seemed to many like a bad idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland — The Rev. David Latimer thought it was a terrible idea. The streets of this Northern Irish city had burned in the Troubles. His Protestant church was firebombed by Catholics. Every summer, rival bonfires the size of small mountains still burn, and with them the flags and effigies of the other side.

articles.headline: Germanwings Pilot Andreas Lubitz Sought Treatment for Vision Problems Before Crash, Authorities Say
articles.snippet: The revelation adds a new element to the portrait of the German co-pilot, who officials say was also being treated for psychological issues.
articles.abstract: The revelation adds a new element to the portrait of the German co-pilot, who officials say was also being treated for psychological issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Andreas Lubitz, who was flying the Germanwings jetliner that slammed into a mountain in the French Alps on Tuesday, sought treatment for vision problems that may have jeopardized his ability to continue working as a pilot, two officials with knowledge of the investigation said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy, Nicholas Kulish, Nicola Clark and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: At U.S. Companies, Time to Coax the Directors Into Talking
articles.snippet: Board members of European companies routinely make themselves available to investors, but their peers in the United States seem to fear such contact.
articles.abstract: Board members of European companies routinely make themselves available to investors, but their peers in the United States seem to fear such contact.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s shareholder meeting season again, corporate America’s version of Groundhog Day.

articles.headline: No. 2 Negotiators in Iran Talks Argue Physics Behind Politics
articles.snippet: Forty years after they both attended M.I.T., the nuclear scientists Ernest J. Moniz and Ali Akbar Salehi have emerged as the No. 2 negotiators on Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: Forty years after they both attended M.I.T., the nuclear scientists Ernest J. Moniz and Ali Akbar Salehi have emerged as the No. 2 negotiators on Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the mid-1970s, Ernest J. Moniz was an up-and-coming nuclear scientist in search of tenure, and Ali Akbar Salehi, a brilliant Iranian graduate student, was finishing a dissertation on fast-neutron reactors.

articles.headline: Wanted at the White House: A Fence That Says Halt! (With Curb Appeal)
articles.snippet: As the White House fence is altered to boost security, the Secret Service must balance a design that thwarts intruders but that doesn’t introduce a prison or Soviet style.
articles.abstract: As the White House fence is altered to boost security, the Secret Service must balance a design that thwarts intruders but that doesn’t introduce a prison or Soviet style.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just after a Secret Service official shouted “Go!” and started a stopwatch, an agent hurtled toward a 10-foot-high fence with curving rods at the top.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: To Avert Repeat of 2008, Clinton Team Hopes to Keep Bill at His Best
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers are trying to harness her husband’s gifts and rein in his impulses to avoid a repeat of her 2008 presidential campaign, when he was often a frustrated and unpredictable presence.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers are trying to harness her husband’s gifts and rein in his impulses to avoid a repeat of her 2008 presidential campaign, when he was often a frustrated and unpredictable presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton’s hearing has faded. With his head of white hair and frail frame, he looks older than his 68 years — “truly grandfatherly,” as one friend said. He often jokes about what would happen if he were to “drop dead.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Germanwings Crash Raises Questions About Shifting Ideas of Pilot Fitness
articles.snippet: Aviation experts say that most screening programs in Europe and the United States are based on an honor system that relies on pilots volunteering information about their mental health.
articles.abstract: Aviation experts say that most screening programs in Europe and the United States are based on an honor system that relies on pilots volunteering information about their mental health.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aviation agencies in Europe and the United States once banned all pilots from flying if they disclosed a mental illness to their employers.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Question in Boston Bombing Trial: For Tsarnaev to Testify or Not
articles.snippet: While it is rare for defendants in criminal trials to take the stand, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev could testify anytime after the prosecution rests, if his lawyers decide he would help his case.
articles.abstract: While it is rare for defendants in criminal trials to take the stand, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev could testify anytime after the prosecution rests, if his lawyers decide he would help his case.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — He swaggers into the courtroom. Freed of handcuffs and leg manacles, he occasionally taps the witness box on his way to the defense table, where he takes his place between two lawyers. During most of the proceedings, he slouches in his chair like a bored student, picking at his goatee, his mind somewhere else.

articles.headline: 2016 Hopefuls and Wealthy Are Aligned on Inequality
articles.snippet: The Republicans Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul and the Democrat Hillary Clinton agree that the income gap is a problem but diverge from public opinion on how to solve it.
articles.abstract: The Republicans Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul and the Democrat Hillary Clinton agree that the income gap is a problem but diverge from public opinion on how to solve it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Appearing at a candidate forum in late January, three likely Republican presidential contenders — Senators Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul — all made a striking confession: They considered “the increasing gap between rich and poor” to be a problem.

articles.headline: News Companies See Movies as Opportunity for Growth
articles.snippet: Some of the most aggressive contemporary purveyors of information, journalistic and otherwise, are betting on feature-length motion pictures.
articles.abstract: Some of the most aggressive contemporary purveyors of information, journalistic and otherwise, are betting on feature-length motion pictures.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the digital wizards at a forward-leaning media company last year introduced their newest idea, an entertainment unit, they couldn’t resist an antique touch: “BuzzFeed Motion Pictures” arrived with a video logo modeled on images from a primitive movie projector called a zoopraxiscope, invented by one Eadweard Muybridge, circa 1879.

articles.headline: Grown-Ups Get Out Their Crayons
articles.snippet: Johanna Basford, a Scottish illustrator, has become a breakout success catering to an unexpected audience: adults who turn to coloring books for creative relaxation.
articles.abstract: Johanna Basford, a Scottish illustrator, has become a breakout success catering to an unexpected audience: adults who turn to coloring books for creative relaxation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may surprise fans of Johanna Basford’s intricately hand-drawn coloring books that the artist is, by her own admission, “pretty bad” at coloring.

articles.headline: Secrecy on the Set: Hollywood Embraces Digital Security
articles.snippet: To better protect scripts, casting decisions, budgets and other sensitive files, filmmakers are turning to new tools to thwart hackers and block prying eyes.
articles.abstract: To better protect scripts, casting decisions, budgets and other sensitive files, filmmakers are turning to new tools to thwart hackers and block prying eyes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Lulu Zezza has played one of the toughest roles in Hollywood.

articles.headline: Foreclosure to Home Free, as 5-Year Clock Expires
articles.snippet: Thousands of homeowners who stopped paying mortgages years ago may have an out as statutes of limitations expire, though banks are fighting back.
articles.abstract: Thousands of homeowners who stopped paying mortgages years ago may have an out as statutes of limitations expire, though banks are fighting back.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In September, Susan Rodolfi celebrated an unusual anniversary: five years of missed mortgage payments.

articles.headline: Jeb Bush and Scott Walker Point G.O.P. to Contrary Paths
articles.snippet: Mr. Bush and Mr. Walker are becoming prominent exponents of dueling visions of how a Republican can retake the White House: by extending the party’s reach, or by energizing the base.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bush and Mr. Walker are becoming prominent exponents of dueling visions of how a Republican can retake the White House: by extending the party’s reach, or by energizing the base.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.H. — As Jeb Bush mingled with Hispanic workers on a company tour a few weeks ago on his first trip here as an all-but-declared candidate for president, he was able to guess the region in Colombia where one woman was born just from hearing her accent.

articles.headline: Jet Crash Tests Germany’s Faith in Its Precision
articles.snippet: Andreas Lubitz, in deliberately crashing a plane, has upended Germany’s well-ordered world and challenged other assumptions built into German life.
articles.abstract: Andreas Lubitz, in deliberately crashing a plane, has upended Germany’s well-ordered world and challenged other assumptions built into German life.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Even in the nightmarish immediate aftermath of the plane crash in the French Alps on Tuesday, Carsten Spohr, the former pilot who runs Germany’s Lufthansa airline, was sure of one thing: the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, 27, was “100 percent” fit to fly.

articles.headline: Iran Backs Away From Key Detail in Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: With a negotiating deadline on Tuesday, Iranian officials have backed away from a critical element of a proposed nuclear agreement, saying they are no longer willing to ship their atomic fuel out of the country.
articles.abstract: With a negotiating deadline on Tuesday, Iranian officials have backed away from a critical element of a proposed nuclear agreement, saying they are no longer willing to ship their atomic fuel out of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — With a negotiating deadline just two days away, Iranian officials on Sunday backed away from a critical element of a proposed nuclear agreement, saying they are no longer willing to ship their atomic fuel out of the country.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say
articles.snippet: The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday.
articles.abstract: The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Before he received his pilot’s license or achieved his dream of flying passenger jets, the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings jetliner was so troubled that he underwent treatment for “suicidal tendencies,” a prosecutor said Monday, raising questions about what the airline should have known about his condition.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Indiana Races to Fight H.I.V. Surge Tied to Drug Abuse
articles.snippet: The worst outbreak in Indiana’s history, which stems largely from the intravenous use of the prescription painkiller Opana, has prompted a whirlwind response effort.
articles.abstract: The worst outbreak in Indiana’s history, which stems largely from the intravenous use of the prescription painkiller Opana, has prompted a whirlwind response effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Ind. — Jeanni McCarty, a nurse and native of this threadbare city of 4,200, hurried up and down Main Street in Saturday’s bright sun, handing out stacks of fliers to any business that would take them. They were announcing a hastily planned specialty clinic — FREE, they emphasized in red — that would provide H.I.V. treatment to anyone who needed it.
